abstract.p: List of books currently in favor with business executives (S)

block.p: Jim Barton, 42 Senior vice president, TiVo BOOK:Dancing Naked in the Mind Field by Kary Mullis (1998) WHY:This is an off-beat autobiography by the Nobel-Prize winning inventor of the polymerase chain reaction (P.C.R.), the foundation of modern bioengineering. Mullis is an original and sometimes truly weird thinker who often challenges both scientific and cultural dogma.

Mullis is an original and sometimes truly weird thinker who often challenges both scientific and cultural dogma.

Mark P. McDonald, 37 Center for Process Excellence Director, Andersen Consulting BOOK:Beowulf translated by Seamus Heaney (2000) WHY:'Beowulf' is the latest in a series of classics I am reading to bring me back to those longer-running themes that, regardless of how hard you try, don't really change. From 'Beowulf' I learned a deeper meaning of the power of story in getting people to act, the power of heritage, since large portions of the book talk about the exploits of prior kings and their deeds. These exploits give the characters the courage to act, as they view themselves as just as brave as their ancestors.

JoeSipher, 36 Vice president, Handspring BOOK:The Humane Interfaceby Jef Raskin (2000) WHY:As a product designer, I'm always looking for new angles ongreat product usability. Raskin does a nice job of des-cribing how to build interfaces that work with natural human behavior.

Shirley F. Moulton, 48 President, Universal Solutions BOOK:Going Home to Teach by Anthony C. Winkler (1995) WHY:I left Jamaica in 1971 and 'Going Home to Teach' gave me an acute understanding of what life was like, politically, socially and economically, after I left the island -- and it had really changed.

Shilpi Somaya, 29 Vice president, Guru.com BOOK:Real Power: Business Lessons from the Tao Te Ching by James A. Autry and Stephen Mitchell (1998) WHY:This book takes age-old lessons from the ancient Chinese text, and draws out applications to business challenges. By using analogies and examples, the authors help address the perennial questions of management.
